1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Watco Transloading, LLC (Watco) is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to an accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at Watco Refugio. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release does occur, our Emergency Action Plan is used to mitigate the effects of the release. We are also coordinated with Miller Environmental which provides additional emergency response expertise.

2.	Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
Watco Refugio's primary activities include storing and coordinating shipping destinations of train rail cars which contain regulated substances. There are 10 regulated substances present at Watco Refugio in quantities grater than or equal to their threshold quantities. These substances are listed as follows with their CAS numbers in parenthesis:
1-Chloropropene (590-21-6)
2-Chloropropane (75-29-6)
2-Chloropropene (557-98-2)
Acrylonitrile (107-13-1)
Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride (7647-01-0)
Chlorine (7782-50-5)
Chloroform (67-66-3)
Epichlorohydrin (106-89-8)
Methyl Chloride (74-87-3)
Propylene (115-07-1)

3.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
Watco Refugio has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. This process is also subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.

The following sections describe the elements of our release prevention program that are in place at Watco Refugio.

Process Safety Information
Watco maintains Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for each regulated substance which describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs.

Process Hazards Analysis
Watco conducted an initial study to ensur

e that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled efficiently. Due to having a simplistic process, a What-If/Checklist method was used. This study was performed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise contained as required in the regulation. Watco plans to ensure the process hazards analysis is updated at least every 5 years and/or after a major process change has occurred.

Operating Procedures
Written operating procedures are kept and maintained at the Refugio Terminal. These procedures address each step of the operating phase including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround. These procedures are easily accessible onsite to all Watco personnel. The procedures are reviewed regularly on a schedule maintained by Watco. These reviews ensure that safety and health considerations are considered to maintain a safe working operation for personnel and local surroundings.

Training
Watco has a training program in place that ensures personnel are competent in the operating procedures and hazards associated with this process. New employees receive initial training and refresher training is required by all employees at least every three years. The specific training topics and frequency are maintained with Watco's "Training Topics Matrix".

Mechanical Integrity
Watco has written maintenance procedures for the facility to ensure continuing proper function. Tank rail cars are inspected upon arrival for any deficiencies. If any deficiencies are found, Watco personnel contact the rail car owner for instructions on how the car will be repaired and by which rail car shop. Watco personnel do not personally perform maintenance on any rail cars.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Personnel whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process con

ditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Safety Review
Pre-startup safety reviews for new and modified processes are conducted as a regular practice at the Refugio Terminal. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to starting a process after a significant change has occurred. Significant changes are those that require a change in the process safety information. Training of personnel is also performed for each employee involved in the affected process.

Compliance Audits
Watco conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every 3 years. Any corrective actions required as a result of an audit are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
Watco investigates incidents that have resulted in, or could have resulted in, an employee injury or significant release of hazardous material. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident and to determine appropriate corrective actions to help prevent the incident from reoccurring. Investigation reports include the date of the incident, investigation start date, description of the incident, factoring contributing to the incident, and recommendations.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Watco strives to maintain a culture where employees are openly involved with process safety management and feel free to express their views or concerns regarding accident/release prevention. Employees are also encouraged to suggest recommendations to help improve process safety. In addition, all employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation to the RMP rule.

Hot Work Permit
Watco maintains a hot work permit program that ensures hot work perform

ed near the covered process is controlled. The hot work permit documents and ensures that all the fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) are implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.

Contractors
Watco ensure that prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures from the Emergency Action Plan  should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. Contractor post-work evaluations are conducted to ensure compliance with Watco safety and health procedures.

4.	Five Year Accident History
Since the Refugio Terminal is a new facility, there are no accidental releases related to this facility. Any accident that results in death, injury, significant property damage, offsite consequences or major releases will be maintained as part of this Five Year Accident History.

5.	Emergency Action Plan
Watco follows an internal emergency action plan that instructs in the proper handling of accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes direction on responsibility assignments, reporting, evacuation, exit routes, medical services, fire extinguishers, hot work, hazardous waste operations, and employee training. The general procedure is for personnel to report all fires and other emergencies to the EAP manager as soon as possible. The EAP manager will then coordinate with local community and emergency response personnel as needed. If the EAP manager is not available, the assistant EAP manager assumes these roles. If neither of these people can be reached, operations personnel are able to call or radio local emergency response which contact numbers are located at each phone throughout the facility.

Watco personnel are instructed not to fight any fires larger than can be controlled with a fire extinguisher, and to never assist in search and rescue within a burning building or advanced medical treatment. Instead, they ar

e to call emergency response and evacuate the facility as necessary. All emergency actions and procedures are coordinate with Miller Environmental who will assist in the emergency action plan.

The emergency action plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the facility that would require an update to the plan.
